original_title: Sri Lanka EFF goes to IMF Executive Board on March 20
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s International Monetary Fund program will be taken up by the International Monetary Fund’s Executive Board on March 20, 2023, after the China gave assurances to re-structure debt.
“Sri Lanka has now received financing assurances from all major bilateral creditors,”  Krishna Srinivasan, Director of IMF’;s Asia and Pacific Department said in a statement.
“This paves the way for consideration by the IMF’s Board on March 20 the approval of the Staff Level Agreement reached on September 1, 2022 for financing under an Extended Fund Facility.”
Approval by the Board would also catalyze financing from other creditors, including the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.

“The arrangement will support the authorities’ program of ambitious reforms, that they have already embarked upon, which will help Sri Lanka emerge from its current crisis and set it on a trajectory of strong and inclusive growth.”

Sri Lanka is going to the IMF for the 17th time. The island suffered currency crises and output shocks after a soft-pegged central bank was set up in 1950 allowing the agency to engage in both exchange rate and monetary policy (printing money to suppress rates).

A new monetary law draft brings back exchange rate policy (which was dropped in the last reform as open market operations were started in the 1990s) and also output gap targeting. (Colombo/Mar07/2023)
